Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A parishioner makes a general inquiry about the possibility of scheduling a chat sometime in the future.
Story: I stared at my screen, the cursor blinking accusingly on the half-finished design document. Slack notifications pinged relentlessly—product managers and designers from other teams were waiting for my technical input, and the deadline was looming. My mind raced with architecture diagrams and API endpoints, but my phone buzzed with a different kind of urgency. A parishioner had messaged, asking if I might have time to talk, not now, but sometime soon. I knew from experience that “sometime” often meant “as soon as you can.” As a priest, I was expected to be present, to listen, to offer comfort and guidance, especially when someone reached out, even tentatively. But as a developer, my team depended on me to deliver, to keep the project moving. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—one demanding my technical expertise, the other my compassion. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between drafting a reply and finishing my document, my heart caught in the tension of two callings that suddenly felt impossibly far apart.
